t: Job 1
Prologue
In*p the land of Uz there lived a man whose name was Job. This man was blameless and upright; he feared God and shunned evil.
He had seven sons and three daughters,

and he owned seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen and five hundred donkeys, and had a large number of servants. He was the greatest man among all the people of the East.
His*p sons used to hold feasts in their homes on their birthdays, and they would invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

When a period of feasting had run its course, Job would make arrangements for them to be purified. Early in the morning he would sacrifice a burnt offering for each of them, thinking, “Perhaps my children have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” This was Job’s regular custom.
One*p day the angels came to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan also came with them.
The Lord*s said to Satan, “Where have you come from?” Satan*p answered the Lord,*s “From roaming throughout the earth, going back and forth on it.”
Then*p the Lord*s said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil.”
“Does*p Job fear God for nothing?” Satan replied.
“Have you not put a hedge around him and his household and everything he has? You have blessed the work of his hands, so that his flocks and herds are spread throughout the land.
But now stretch out your hand and strike everything he has, and he will surely curse you to your face.”
The*p Lord*s said to Satan, “Very well, then, everything he has is in your power, but on the man himself do not lay a finger.” Then*p Satan went out from the presence of the Lord.*s
One*p day when Job’s sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother’s house,
a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the donkeys were grazing nearby,
and the Sabeans attacked and made off with them. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
While*p he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, “The fire of God fell from the heavens and burned up the sheep and the servants, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”

While*p he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three raiding parties and swept down on your camels and made off with them. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
While*p he was still speaking, yet another messenger came and said, “Your sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother’s house,
when suddenly a mighty wind swept in from the desert and struck the four corners of the house. It collapsed on them and they are dead, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
At*p this, Job got up and tore his robe and shaved his head. Then he fell to the ground in worship
and said: “Naked*pn I came from my mother’s womb, and*ld naked I will depart. The*ln Lord*s gave and the Lord*s has taken away; may*ld the name of the Lord*s be praised.”
In*p all this, Job did not sin by charging God with wrongdoing.
Job 2
On*p another day the angels came to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan also came with them to present himself before him.
And the Lord*s said to Satan, “Where have you come from?” Satan*p answered the Lord,*s “From roaming throughout the earth, going back and forth on it.”

Then*p the Lord*s said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil. And he still maintains his integrity, though you incited me against him to ruin him without any reason.”
“Skin*p for skin!” Satan replied. “A man will give all he has for his own life.
But now stretch out your hand and strike his flesh and bones, and he will surely curse you to your face.”
The*p Lord*s said to Satan, “Very well, then, he is in your hands; but you must spare his life.”
So*p Satan went out from the presence of the Lord*s and afflicted Job with painful sores from the soles of his feet to the crown of his head.
Then Job took a piece of broken pottery and scraped himself with it as he sat among the ashes.
His*p wife said to him, “Are you still maintaining your integrity? Curse God and die!”
He*p replied, “You are talking like a foolish woman. Shall we accept good from God, and not trouble?” In*p all this, Job did not sin in what he said.

When*p Job’s three friends, Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite, heard about all the troubles that had come upon him, they set out from their homes and met together by agreement to go and sympathize with him and comfort him.
When they saw him from a distance, they could hardly recognize him; they began to weep aloud, and they tore their robes and sprinkled dust on their heads.
Then they sat on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights. No one said a word to him, because they saw how great his suffering was.
Job 3
Job Speaks
After*p this, Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.
He said:
“May*pn the day of my birth perish, and*ld the night that said, ‘A boy is conceived!’
That*ln day—may it turn to darkness; may*ld God above not care about it; may*ld no light shine on it.
May*ln gloom and utter darkness claim it once more; may*ld a cloud settle over it; may*ld blackness overwhelm it.
That*ln night—may thick darkness seize it; may*ld it not be included among the days of the year nor*ld be entered in any of the months.
May*ln that night be barren; may*ld no shout of joy be heard in it.
May*ln those who curse days curse that day, those*ld who are ready to rouse Leviathan.
May*ln its morning stars become dark; may*ld it wait for daylight in vain and*ld not see the first rays of dawn,
for*ln it did not shut the doors of the womb on me to*ld hide trouble from my eyes.
“Why*pn did I not perish at birth, and*ld die as I came from the womb?
Why*ln were there knees to receive me and*ld breasts that I might be nursed?
For*ln now I would be lying down in peace; I*ld would be asleep and at rest
with*ln kings and rulers of the earth, who*ld built for themselves places now lying in ruins,
with*ln princes who had gold, who*ld filled their houses with silver.
Or*ln why was I not hidden away in the ground like a stillborn child, like*ld an infant who never saw the light of day?
There*ln the wicked cease from turmoil, and*ld there the weary are at rest.
Captives*ln also enjoy their ease; they*ld no longer hear the slave driver’s shout.
The*ln small and the great are there, and*ld the slaves are freed from their owners.
“Why*pn is light given to those in misery, and*ld life to the bitter of soul,
to*ln those who long for death that does not come, who*ld search for it more than for hidden treasure,
who*ln are filled with gladness and*ld rejoice when they reach the grave?
Why*ln is life given to a man whose*ld way is hidden, whom*ld God has hedged in?
For*ln sighing has become my daily food; my*ld groans pour out like water.
What*ln I feared has come upon me; what*ld I dreaded has happened to me.
I*ln have no peace, no quietness; I*ld have no rest, but only turmoil.”
Job 4
Eliphaz
Then*p Eliphaz the Temanite replied:
“If*pn someone ventures a word with you, will you be impatient? But*ld who can keep from speaking?
Think*ln how you have instructed many, how*ld you have strengthened feeble hands.
Your*ln words have supported those who stumbled; you*ld have strengthened faltering knees.
But*ln now trouble comes to you, and you are discouraged; it*ld strikes you, and you are dismayed.
Should*ln not your piety be your confidence and*ld your blameless ways your hope?
“Consider*pn now: Who, being innocent, has ever perished? Where*ld were the upright ever destroyed?
As*ln I have observed, those who plow evil and*ld those who sow trouble reap it.
At*ln the breath of God they perish; at*ld the blast of his anger they are no more.
The*ln lions may roar and growl, yet*ld the teeth of the great lions are broken.
The*ln lion perishes for lack of prey, and*ld the cubs of the lioness are scattered.
“A*pn word was secretly brought to me, my*ld ears caught a whisper of it.
Amid*ln disquieting dreams in the night, when*ld deep sleep falls on people,
fear*ln and trembling seized me and*ld made all my bones shake.
A*ln spirit glided past my face, and*ld the hair on my body stood on end.
It*ln stopped, but*ld I could not tell what it was. A*ln form stood before my eyes, and*ld I heard a hushed voice:
‘Can*ln a mortal be more righteous than God? Can*ld even a strong man be more pure than his Maker?
If*ln God places no trust in his servants, if*ld he charges his angels with error,
how*ln much more those who live in houses of clay, whose*ld foundations are in the dust, who*ld are crushed more readily than a moth!
Between*ln dawn and dusk they are broken to pieces; unnoticed,*ld they perish forever.
Are*ln not the cords of their tent pulled up, so*ld that they die without wisdom?’
Job 5
“Call*pn if you will, but who will answer you? To*ld which of the holy ones will you turn?
Resentment*ln kills a fool, and*ld envy slays the simple.
I*ln myself have seen a fool taking root, but*ld suddenly his house was cursed.
His*ln children are far from safety, crushed*ld in court without a defender.
The*ln hungry consume his harvest, taking*ld it even from among thorns, and*ld the thirsty pant after his wealth.
For*ln hardship does not spring from the soil, nor*ld does trouble sprout from the ground.
Yet*ln man is born to trouble as*ld surely as sparks fly upward.
“But*pn if I were you, I would appeal to God; I*ld would lay my cause before him.
He*ln performs wonders that cannot be fathomed, miracles*ld that cannot be counted.
He*ln provides rain for the earth; he*ld sends water on the countryside.
The*ln lowly he sets on high, and*ld those who mourn are lifted to safety.
He*ln thwarts the plans of the crafty, so*ld that their hands achieve no success.
He*ln catches the wise in their craftiness, and*ld the schemes of the wily are swept away.
Darkness*ln comes upon them in the daytime; at*ld noon they grope as in the night.
He*ln saves the needy from the sword in their mouth; he*ld saves them from the clutches of the powerful.
So*ln the poor have hope, and*ld injustice shuts its mouth.
“Blessed*pn is the one whom God corrects; so*ld do not despise the discipline of the Almighty.
For*ln he wounds, but he also binds up; he*ld injures, but his hands also heal.
From*ln six calamities he will rescue you; in*ld seven no harm will touch you.
In*ln famine he will deliver you from death, and*ld in battle from the stroke of the sword.
You*ln will be protected from the lash of the tongue, and*ld need not fear when destruction comes.
You*ln will laugh at destruction and famine, and*ld need not fear the wild animals.
For*ln you will have a covenant with the stones of the field, and*ld the wild animals will be at peace with you.
You*ln will know that your tent is secure; you*ld will take stock of your property and find nothing missing.
You*ln will know that your children will be many, and*ld your descendants like the grass of the earth.
You*ln will come to the grave in full vigor, like*ld sheaves gathered in season.
“We*pn have examined this, and it is true. So*ld hear it and apply it to yourself.”
Job 6
Job
Then*p Job replied:
“If*pn only my anguish could be weighed and*ld all my misery be placed on the scales!
It*ln would surely outweigh the sand of the seas— no*ld wonder my words have been impetuous.
The*ln arrows of the Almighty are in me, my*ld spirit drinks in their poison; God’s*ld terrors are marshaled against me.
Does*ln a wild donkey bray when it has grass, or*ld an ox bellow when it has fodder?
Is*ln tasteless food eaten without salt, or*ld is there flavor in the sap of the mallow?
I*ln refuse to touch it; such*ld food makes me ill.
“Oh,*pn that I might have my request, that*ld God would grant what I hope for,
that*ln God would be willing to crush me, to*ld let loose his hand and cut off my life!
Then*ln I would still have this consolation— my*ld joy in unrelenting pain— that*ld I had not denied the words of the Holy One.
“What*pn strength do I have, that I should still hope? What*ld prospects, that I should be patient?
Do*ln I have the strength of stone? Is*ld my flesh bronze?
Do*ln I have any power to help myself, now*ld that success has been driven from me?
“Anyone*pn who withholds kindness from a friend forsakes*ld the fear of the Almighty.
But*ln my brothers are as undependable as intermittent streams, as*ld the streams that overflow
when*ln darkened by thawing ice and*ld swollen with melting snow,
but*ln that stop flowing in the dry season, and*ld in the heat vanish from their channels.
Caravans*ln turn aside from their routes; they*ld go off into the wasteland and perish.
The*ln caravans of Tema look for water, the*ld traveling merchants of Sheba look in hope.
They*ln are distressed, because they had been confident; they*ld arrive there, only to be disappointed.
Now*ln you too have proved to be of no help; you*ld see something dreadful and are afraid.
Have*ln I ever said, ‘Give something on my behalf, pay*ld a ransom for me from your wealth,
deliver*ln me from the hand of the enemy, rescue*ld me from the clutches of the ruthless’?
“Teach*pn me, and I will be quiet; show*ld me where I have been wrong.
How*ln painful are honest words! But*ld what do your arguments prove?
Do*ln you mean to correct what I say, and*ld treat my desperate words as wind?
You*ln would even cast lots for the fatherless and*ld barter away your friend.
“But*pn now be so kind as to look at me. Would*ld I lie to your face?
Relent,*ln do not be unjust; reconsider,*ld for my integrity is at stake.
Is*ln there any wickedness on my lips? Can*ld my mouth not discern malice?
Job 7
“Do*pn not mortals have hard service on earth? Are*ld not their days like those of hired laborers?
Like*ln a slave longing for the evening shadows, or*ld a hired laborer waiting to be paid,
so*ln I have been allotted months of futility, and*ld nights of misery have been assigned to me.
When*ln I lie down I think, ‘How long before I get up?’ The*ld night drags on, and I toss and turn until dawn.
My*ln body is clothed with worms and scabs, my*ld skin is broken and festering.
“My*pn days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle, and*ld they come to an end without hope.
Remember,*ln O God, that my life is but a breath; my*ld eyes will never see happiness again.
The*ln eye that now sees me will see me no longer; you*ld will look for me, but I will be no more.
As*ln a cloud vanishes and is gone, so*ld one who goes down to the grave does not return.
He*ln will never come to his house again; his*ld place will know him no more.
“Therefore*pn I will not keep silent; I*ld will speak out in the anguish of my spirit, I*ld will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
Am*ln I the sea, or the monster of the deep, that*ld you put me under guard?
When*ln I think my bed will comfort me and*ld my couch will ease my complaint,
even*ln then you frighten me with dreams and*ld terrify me with visions,
so*ln that I prefer strangling and death, rather*ld than this body of mine.
I*ln despise my life; I would not live forever. Let*ld me alone; my days have no meaning.
“What*pn is mankind that you make so much of them, that*ld you give them so much attention,
that*ln you examine them every morning and*ld test them every moment?
Will*ln you never look away from me, or*ld let me alone even for an instant?
If*ln I have sinned, what have I done to you, you*ld who see everything we do? Why*ln have you made me your target? Have*ld I become a burden to you?
Why*ln do you not pardon my offenses and*ld forgive my sins? For*ln I will soon lie down in the dust; you*ld will search for me, but I will be no more.”
Job 8
Bildad
Then*p Bildad the Shuhite replied:
“How*pn long will you say such things? Your*ld words are a blustering wind.
Does*ln God pervert justice? Does*ld the Almighty pervert what is right?
When*ln your children sinned against him, he*ld gave them over to the penalty of their sin.
But*ln if you will seek God earnestly and*ld plead with the Almighty,
if*ln you are pure and upright, even*ld now he will rouse himself on your behalf and*ld restore you to your prosperous state.
Your*ln beginnings will seem humble, so*ld prosperous will your future be.
“Ask*pn the former generation and*ld find out what their ancestors learned,
for*ln we were born only yesterday and know nothing, and*ld our days on earth are but a shadow.
Will*ln they not instruct you and tell you? Will*ld they not bring forth words from their understanding?
Can*ln papyrus grow tall where there is no marsh? Can*ld reeds thrive without water?
While*ln still growing and uncut, they*ld wither more quickly than grass.
Such*ln is the destiny of all who forget God; so*ld perishes the hope of the godless.
What*ln they trust in is fragile; what*ld they rely on is a spider’s web.
They*ln lean on the web, but it gives way; they*ld cling to it, but it does not hold.
They*ln are like a well-watered plant in the sunshine, spreading*ld its shoots over the garden;
it*ln entwines its roots around a pile of rocks and*ld looks for a place among the stones.
But*ln when it is torn from its spot, that*ld place disowns it and says, ‘I never saw you.’
Surely*ln its life withers away, and*ld from the soil other plants grow.
“Surely*pn God does not reject one who is blameless or*ld strengthen the hands of evildoers.
He*ln will yet fill your mouth with laughter and*ld your lips with shouts of joy.
Your*ln enemies will be clothed in shame, and*ld the tents of the wicked will be no more.”
Job 9
Job
Then*p Job replied:
“Indeed,*pn I know that this is true. But*ld how can mere mortals prove their innocence before God?
Though*ln they wished to dispute with him, they*ld could not answer him one time out of a thousand.
His*ln wisdom is profound, his power is vast. Who*ld has resisted him and come out unscathed?
He*ln moves mountains without their knowing it and*ld overturns them in his anger.
He*ln shakes the earth from its place and*ld makes its pillars tremble.
He*ln speaks to the sun and it does not shine; he*ld seals off the light of the stars.
He*ln alone stretches out the heavens and*ld treads on the waves of the sea.
He*ln is the Maker of the Bear and Orion, the*ld Pleiades and the constellations of the south.
He*ln performs wonders that cannot be fathomed, miracles*ld that cannot be counted.
When*ln he passes me, I cannot see him; when*ld he goes by, I cannot perceive him.
If*ln he snatches away, who can stop him? Who*ld can say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
God*ln does not restrain his anger; even*ld the cohorts of Rahab cowered at his feet.
“How*pn then can I dispute with him? How*ld can I find words to argue with him?
Though*ln I were innocent, I could not answer him; I*ld could only plead with my Judge for mercy.
Even*ln if I summoned him and he responded, I*ld do not believe he would give me a hearing.
He*ln would crush me with a storm and*ld multiply my wounds for no reason.
He*ln would not let me catch my breath but*ld would overwhelm me with misery.
If*ln it is a matter of strength, he is mighty! And*ld if it is a matter of justice, who can challenge him?
Even*ln if I were innocent, my mouth would condemn me; if*ld I were blameless, it would pronounce me guilty.
“Although*pn I am blameless, I*ld have no concern for myself; I*ld despise my own life.
It*ln is all the same; that is why I say, ‘He*ld destroys both the blameless and the wicked.’
When*ln a scourge brings sudden death, he*ld mocks the despair of the innocent.
When*ln a land falls into the hands of the wicked, he*ld blindfolds its judges. If*ld it is not he, then who is it?
“My*pn days are swifter than a runner; they*ld fly away without a glimpse of joy.
They*ln skim past like boats of papyrus, like*ld eagles swooping down on their prey.
If*ln I say, ‘I will forget my complaint, I*ld will change my expression, and smile,’
I*ln still dread all my sufferings, for*ld I know you will not hold me innocent.
Since*ln I am already found guilty, why*ld should I struggle in vain?
Even*ln if I washed myself with soap and*ld my hands with cleansing powder,
you*ln would plunge me into a slime pit so*ld that even my clothes would detest me.
“He*pn is not a mere mortal like me that I might answer him, that*ld we might confront each other in court.
If*ln only there were someone to mediate between us, someone*ld to bring us together,
someone*ln to remove God’s rod from me, so*ld that his terror would frighten me no more.
Then*ln I would speak up without fear of him, but*ld as it now stands with me, I cannot.
Job 10
“I*pn loathe my very life; therefore*ld I will give free rein to my complaint and*ld speak out in the bitterness of my soul.
I*ln say to God: Do not declare me guilty, but*ld tell me what charges you have against me.
Does*ln it please you to oppress me, to*ld spurn the work of your hands, while*ld you smile on the plans of the wicked?
Do*ln you have eyes of flesh? Do*ld you see as a mortal sees?
Are*ln your days like those of a mortal or*ld your years like those of a strong man,
that*ln you must search out my faults and*ld probe after my sin—
though*ln you know that I am not guilty and*ld that no one can rescue me from your hand?
“Your*pn hands shaped me and made me. Will*ld you now turn and destroy me?
Remember*ln that you molded me like clay. Will*ld you now turn me to dust again?
Did*ln you not pour me out like milk and*ld curdle me like cheese,
clothe*ln me with skin and flesh and*ld knit me together with bones and sinews?
You*ln gave me life and showed me kindness, and*ld in your providence watched over my spirit.
“But*pn this is what you concealed in your heart, and*ld I know that this was in your mind:
If*ln I sinned, you would be watching me and*ld would not let my offense go unpunished.
If*ln I am guilty—woe to me! Even*ld if I am innocent, I cannot lift my head, for*ln I am full of shame and*ld drowned in my affliction.
If*ln I hold my head high, you stalk me like a lion and*ld again display your awesome power against me.
You*ln bring new witnesses against me and*ld increase your anger toward me; your*ld forces come against me wave upon wave.
“Why*pn then did you bring me out of the womb? I*ld wish I had died before any eye saw me.
If*ln only I had never come into being, or*ld had been carried straight from the womb to the grave!
Are*ln not my few days almost over? Turn*ld away from me so I can have a moment’s joy
before*ln I go to the place of no return, to*ld the land of gloom and utter darkness,
to*ln the land of deepest night, of*ld utter darkness and disorder, where*ld even the light is like darkness.”
Job 11
Zophar
Then*p Zophar the Naamathite replied:
“Are*pn all these words to go unanswered? Is*ld this talker to be vindicated?
Will*ln your idle talk reduce others to silence? Will*ld no one rebuke you when you mock?
You*ln say to God, ‘My beliefs are flawless and*ld I am pure in your sight.’
Oh,*ln how I wish that God would speak, that*ld he would open his lips against you
and*ln disclose to you the secrets of wisdom, for*ld true wisdom has two sides. Know*ld this: God has even forgotten some of your sin.
“Can*pn you fathom the mysteries of God? Can*ld you probe the limits of the Almighty?
They*ln are higher than the heavens above—what can you do? They*ld are deeper than the depths below—what can you know?
Their*ln measure is longer than the earth and*ld wider than the sea.
“If*pn he comes along and confines you in prison and*ld convenes a court, who can oppose him?
Surely*ln he recognizes deceivers; and*ld when he sees evil, does he not take note?
But*ln the witless can no more become wise than*ld a wild donkey’s colt can be born human.
“Yet*pn if you devote your heart to him and*ld stretch out your hands to him,
if*ln you put away the sin that is in your hand and*ld allow no evil to dwell in your tent,
then,*ln free of fault, you will lift up your face; you*ld will stand firm and without fear.
You*ln will surely forget your trouble, recalling*ld it only as waters gone by.
Life*ln will be brighter than noonday, and*ld darkness will become like morning.
You*ln will be secure, because there is hope; you*ld will look about you and take your rest in safety.
You*ln will lie down, with no one to make you afraid, and*ld many will court your favor.
But*ln the eyes of the wicked will fail, and*ld escape will elude them; their*ld hope will become a dying gasp.”
Job 12
Job
Then*p Job replied:
“Doubtless*pn you are the only people who matter, and*ld wisdom will die with you!
But*ln I have a mind as well as you; I*ld am not inferior to you. Who*ld does not know all these things?
“I*pn have become a laughingstock to my friends, though*ld I called on God and he answered— a*ld mere laughingstock, though righteous and blameless!
Those*ln who are at ease have contempt for misfortune as*ld the fate of those whose feet are slipping.
The*ln tents of marauders are undisturbed, and*ld those who provoke God are secure— those*ld God has in his hand.
“But*pn ask the animals, and they will teach you, or*ld the birds in the sky, and they will tell you;
or*ln speak to the earth, and it will teach you, or*ld let the fish in the sea inform you.
Which*ln of all these does not know that*ld the hand of the Lord*s has done this?
In*ln his hand is the life of every creature and*ld the breath of all mankind.
Does*ln not the ear test words as*ld the tongue tastes food?
Is*ln not wisdom found among the aged? Does*ld not long life bring understanding?
“To*pn God belong wisdom and power; counsel*ld and understanding are his.
What*ln he tears down cannot be rebuilt; those*ld he imprisons cannot be released.
If*ln he holds back the waters, there is drought; if*ld he lets them loose, they devastate the land.
To*ln him belong strength and insight; both*ld deceived and deceiver are his.
He*ln leads rulers away stripped and*ld makes fools of judges.
He*ln takes off the shackles put on by kings and*ld ties a loincloth around their waist.
He*ln leads priests away stripped and*ld overthrows officials long established.
He*ln silences the lips of trusted advisers and*ld takes away the discernment of elders.
He*ln pours contempt on nobles and*ld disarms the mighty.
He*ln reveals the deep things of darkness and*ld brings utter darkness into the light.
He*ln makes nations great, and destroys them; he*ld enlarges nations, and disperses them.
He*ln deprives the leaders of the earth of their reason; he*ld makes them wander in a trackless waste.
They*ln grope in darkness with no light; he*ld makes them stagger like drunkards.
Job 13
“My*pn eyes have seen all this, my*ld ears have heard and understood it.
What*ln you know, I also know; I*ld am not inferior to you.
But*ln I desire to speak to the Almighty and*ld to argue my case with God.
You,*ln however, smear me with lies; you*ld are worthless physicians, all of you!
If*ln only you would be altogether silent! For*ld you, that would be wisdom.
Hear*ln now my argument; listen*ld to the pleas of my lips.
Will*ln you speak wickedly on God’s behalf? Will*ld you speak deceitfully for him?
Will*ln you show him partiality? Will*ld you argue the case for God?
Would*ln it turn out well if he examined you? Could*ld you deceive him as you might deceive a mortal?
He*ln would surely call you to account if*ld you secretly showed partiality.
Would*ln not his splendor terrify you? Would*ld not the dread of him fall on you?
Your*ln maxims are proverbs of ashes; your*ld defenses are defenses of clay.
“Keep*pn silent and let me speak; then*ld let come to me what may.
Why*ln do I put myself in jeopardy and*ld take my life in my hands?
Though*ln he slay me, yet will I hope in him; I*ld will surely defend my ways to his face.
Indeed,*ln this will turn out for my deliverance, for*ld no godless person would dare come before him!
Listen*ln carefully to what I say; let*ld my words ring in your ears.
Now*ln that I have prepared my case, I*ld know I will be vindicated.
Can*ln anyone bring charges against me? If*ld so, I will be silent and die.
“Only*pn grant me these two things, God, and*ld then I will not hide from you:
Withdraw*ln your hand far from me, and*ld stop frightening me with your terrors.
Then*ln summon me and I will answer, or*ld let me speak, and you reply to me.
